title: 115_hr912
content: The Act titled "Protecting Immigrants From Legal Exploitation Act of 2017" addresses schemes involving fraudulent immigration services. The Act "Protecting Immigrants From Legal Exploitation Act of 2017" introduces penalties for schemes providing fraudulent immigration services, including fines and imprisonment for those who defraud or obtain money through false representations. The Act "Protecting Immigrants From Legal Exploitation Act of 2017" imposes penalties, including fines and imprisonment up to 15 years, for individuals who fraudulently provide immigration services. Offenders must also reimburse clients for any fraudulent services rendered. The Act "Protecting Immigrants From Legal Exploitation Act of 2017" imposes penalties for schemes to defraud aliens by providing fraudulent immigration services. The Act "Protecting Immigrants From Legal Exploitation Act of 2017" imposes penalties for fraudulent immigration services, requiring regulations on identifying assistance in preparing immigration submissions and signing forms as a preparer for those who received compensation. The Act "Protecting Immigrants From Legal Exploitation Act of 2017" requires individuals providing immigration services to sign forms as preparers and provide identifying information. The Attorney General can take civil action against fraudulent immigration service providers who misrepresent their legal authority. A service provider, excluding attorneys, who offers assistance to aliens in immigration matters for a fee must comply with regulations. SEC. 4. RELIEF FOR VICTIMS OF NOTARIO FRAUD. An alien can withdraw an immigration application if it was prepared by someone engaged in unauthorized practice of law or fraud. Corrected filings can be resubmitted with a procedure developed by relevant authorities. An alien can withdraw an immigration application if it was prepared by someone engaged in unauthorized practice of law or fraud. Corrected filings can be resubmitted with a procedure developed by relevant authorities, waiving the bar to reentry for those affected by immigration practitioner fraud. The Attorney General must establish regulations within 180 days to enforce the contempt authority of immigration judges, allowing civil contempt sanctions, including monetary penalties, for all parties appearing before the judge. SEC. 5. OUTREACH TO IMMIGRANT COMMUNITIES. The Secretary of Homeland Security and the Attorney General will educate aliens on legal services in immigration proceedings to prevent fraud. The Attorney General will make information on fraud by unauthorized individuals available to aliens. The program authorized by the Secretary of Homeland Security and the Attorney General aims to educate aliens on legal services in immigration proceedings to prevent fraud. Information on fraud by unauthorized individuals will be provided through appropriate offices and websites maintained by the Attorney General. Foreign language materials will be made available in languages such as English and Spanish. Appropriations are authorized for the program, with funds remaining available until expended. Grant program established to assist eligible applicants. Establishment of grant programs within U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services and Executive Office for Immigration Review to award funds to eligible nonprofit organizations providing legal services to immigrants, refugees, and asylum seekers. Funds are to be used for direct assistance in removal proceedings and application completion. Authorization of Appropriations: Sums are authorized to be appropriated for the grant programs to assist immigrants with legal services. Amounts shall remain available until expended.
